questions.text: Which of the following inhibits the rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis?
questions.solution:
The rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis is tyrosine hydroxylase and is inhibited by metyrosine (alpha-methyl-p-tyrosine).

Tyrosine hydroxylase converts tyrosine to dopa (rate-limiting step). Dopa is then converted to dopamine by dopa decarboxylase.

Metyrosine is indicated preoperatively in pheochromocytoma and in inoperable cases.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient has been taking a salbutamol inhaler to control his wheezing episodes. Which of the following is not an effect seen on stimulation of the receptor involved?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol is a short-acting, selective β2-adrenergic receptor agonist used in the treatment of asthma and COPD.  β2 receptors mediate the stimulation of lipolysis (not inhibition). 

Adrenergic control of adipose tissue:

  • Stimulation of lipolysis - α1, β1, β2, and β3 receptors
  • Inhibition of lipolysis - α2
Adrenergic receptor Actions
α1 receptor
  • Vasoconstriction of large arterioles
  • Genito-urinary smooth muscle - contraction
  • Uterine muscles contraction
  • Mydriasis - by contraction of radial muscles of the iris
  • Increase secretion of glands
  • Gastrointestinal relaxation
α2 receptor
  • Autoregulatory in the sympathetic system
  • Vasoconstriction of precapillary arterioles in skeletal muscles
  • Decrease insulin synthesis
β1 receptor
  • Increased rhythmicity and force of contraction of the heart
  • Increased renin secretion - JG cells in the kidney
β2 receptor
  • Smooth muscle relaxation: vasodilation, bronchodilation
  • Uterine muscle relaxation
  • Stimulation of lipolysis
  • Increased insulin secretion
  • Increased hepatic gluconeogenesis
  • Increased muscle glycogenolysis
β3 receptor
  • Stimulation of lipolysis
  • Relaxation of detrusor

questions.text: Which of the following statements most appropriately describes the vasomotor reversal of Dale?

choices.text: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by blockade of beta 2
Stimulation of beta 1 followed by blockade of beta 2

questions.solution:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.

Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces an α1-mediated rise in BP followed by a β2-mediated fall in BP.

Administration of epinephrine after administration of α-blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α-mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β-mediated response is seen, resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the vasomotor reversal of Dale. This was first demonstrated by Sir H.H.Dale.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs when administered would lead to a biphasic reaction on blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Biphasic reaction on blood pressure is seen with the administration of adrenaline. The BP initially rises followed by a fall in BP.

Adrenaline acts on α1, α2, β1, β2, and β3 receptors.

α1 - present in blood vessels - causes vasoconstriction - increases BP.

β2 - present in blood vessels - causes vasodilatation - decreases BP.

At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen. Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline.

Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the β2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen. This is referred to as the biphasic reaction. 

Adrenergic drug

Receptors it acts on

Adrenaline

α1 + α2 +β1 + β2 + weak β3 action

Noradrenaline

α1 +α2 +β1 + β3 but no β2 action

Isoprenaline

β1 + β2 + β3 but no α action

questions.text: Which of the following would not increase with slow IV infusion of adrenaline?
questions.solution:
Slow intravenous infusion of adrenaline results in a significant increase in systolic blood pressure with minimal effect on diastolic pressure. 

Mean blood pressure and pulse pressure increase. This is because of the increased systolic pressure coupled with decreased, unchanged, or an insignificant increase in diastolic pressure.

At lower concentrations of adrenaline, vascular β2 receptors are more sensitive than α receptors, hence peripheral resistance decreases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
IV adrenaline increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
Dopamine increases peripheral resistance and improves renal perfusion
IV isoproterenol increases systolic and decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia

questions.solution:
IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP but is unlikely to cause tachycardia. 

IV noradrenaline acts on α1, α2, and β1 receptors:

  • α1- vasoconstriction - Increases DBP.
  • β1 - increases heart rate and contractility - Increases SBP.
  • This increases mean arterial pressure which causes a reflex vagal activity that decreases the heart rate leading to bradycardia.

IV adrenaline acts on α1, α2, β1, β2, and β3 receptors:

  • β1 - increases SBP, tachycardia.
  • DBP - either β2 - decrease DBP, α1 - increase DBP or α1+β2 - no change. 

Dopamine acts on β1,α1, and D1 receptors:

  • D1 - low concentrations - causes vasodilatation thus improving renal perfusion 
  • β1- positive inotropic effect - increases SBP.
  • α1 - higher infusion rates - causes vasoconstriction and increases peripheral resistance

IV isoproterenol is a non-selective β receptor agonist:

  • β1- increases SBP
  • β2- vasodilatation - decreases DBP
  • β1- tachycardia

questions.text: A patient in low output cardiogenic shock is being treated with dobutamine. Which of the following is true about the drug?

choices.text: Acts on D1 and D2 receptors
Has no effect on coronary circulation

questions.solution:
Dobutamine decreases peripheral resistance minimally.

Clinically, dobutamine increases cardiac output by selectively increasing myocardial contractility and promotes coronary vasodilation. This is associated with a mild decrease in total peripheral vascular resistance, which is mediated by the reflex withdrawal of sympathetic tone to the vasculature.

Dobutamine has a t1/2 of 2 minutes. It resembles dopamine but no action is seen on dopamine receptors.

Renal circulation is variably affected depending upon the sympathetic tone of the patient.

questions.text: During a rotation in the acute medical ward, you observe a patient in cardiogenic shock being started on a low-dose dopamine infusion. Which of the following would you expect to increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
At lower doses (< 2 μg/kg), dopamine only stimulates dopamine receptors in renal vasculature, causing increased urine output.

As the dose increases (2-5 μg/kg), additional cardiac stimulant action (β1) is also seen.

At very high doses (5-15 μg/kg), vasoconstriction (α1) is additionally seen.

questions.text: A stress ECHO has to be done for a 56-year-old COPD patient with high suspicion of coronary artery disease. Which of the following drugs can be used to perform this test?
questions.solution:
Dobutamine is used to perform a stress test.

Stress echocardiography is primarily done for the evaluation of myocardial ischemia. The basic principle is to increase cardiac stress (either with exercise or with a drug) in a controlled fashion, to aid with the identification and localization of ischemic areas (by detecting new or worsening wall motion abnormalities).  

Performing stress echocardiography with a pharmacologic agent such as dobutamine allows for simulation of increased heart rate and increased myocardial physiologic demands in patients who may be unable to exercise due to musculoskeletal or pulmonary comorbidities.

Dobutamine causes cardiac stress by acting on β1-adrenergic receptors to increase cardiac contractility and heart rate, and on β2-adrenergic receptors to cause peripheral vasodilatation. It is preferred over vasodilators used in stress echo tests such as adenosine, dipyridamole, and regadenoson (adenosine derivative).

questions.text: You notice fenoldopam mentioned on the drug chart of an elderly male patient admitted in the ICU. What condition is he most likely being treated for?
questions.solution:
Fenoldopam is primarily indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies. It is a D1 agonist at peripheral D1 receptors and acts as a rapid-acting vasodilator.

Drugs used in a hypertensive emergency are:

  • Nitroprusside
  • Nicardipine
  • Labetalol
  • Hydralazine
  • Esmolol
  • Nitroglycerine
  • Phentolamine
  • Fenoldopam

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indirectly acting sympathomimetic?
questions.solution:
Oxymetazoline is a direct-acting non-selective α1 and α2 receptor agonist.

Amphetamine, methamphetamine, and tyramine are catecholamine releasing agents and are considered to be indirectly acting sympathomimetic agents.

questions.text: Following spinal anesthesia, the blood pressure of a patient started dropping. Your senior asks you to administer a mixed-acting sympathomimetic. Which of the following loaded syringes will you pick?
questions.solution:
Ephedrine is a mixed-acting sympathomimetic agent which can be used to manage hypotension following spinal anesthesia.

Drugs that release norepinephrine and also directly activate receptors are called mixed-acting sympathomimetics.

Ephedrine has a dual action: 

  • Releasing agent: releases neurotransmitters from nerve endings.
  • Direct action on α1, α2, β1, and β2 receptors.

The adrenergic agents are classified into three sub-groups:

  • Directly acting agents:
    • Selective agents - phenylephrine (α1), clonidine (α2), dobutamine (β1), terbutaline (β2).
    • Non-selective agents - oxymetazoline (α1 + α2), isoproterenol (β1 + β2), epinephrine (α1 +α2 +β1 + β2) norepinephrine (α1 +α2 + β1)
  • Mixed acting agents - ephedrine (α1 +α2 +β1 + β2 + catecholamine releasing agent)
  • Indirectly acting agents:
    • Catecholamine releasing agents - amphetamine and tyramine
    • Uptake inhibitor - cocaine
    • MAO inhibitor - selegeline
    • COMT inhibitor - entacapone

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about clonidine?

choices.text: It acts on alpha 2 adrenergic receptors
Can result in rebound hypertension on abrupt withdrawal

questions.solution:
Clonidine is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. It is not associated with CNS stimulation. 

It treats high blood pressure by stimulating presynaptic α2 receptors in the vasomotor center in the brainstem. This binding has a sympatholytic effect, by suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

Option A - Clonidine is an alpha 2 receptor agonist that reduces central sympathetic outflow.

Option B - Abrupt withdrawal after long-term therapy can result in rebound hypertension.

Option D - Dry mouth and sedation are the major side effects of clonidine. It can also cause impotency and constipation.

questions.text: You are administering clonidine intravenously to a patient. Which of the following effects would you observe?

choices.text: Prolonged rapid fall in blood pressure
Transient rise in blood pressure followed by a prolonged fall
Transient fall in blood pressure followed by a prolonged rise
Prolonged rapid rise in blood pressure

questions.solution:
Intravenous administration of clonidine results in a transient rise in blood pressure followed by a prolonged fall.

α2 receptors are present on the presynaptic as well as the postsynaptic ganglia. They are the autoreceptors of the sympathetic system.  

Clonidine is a directly acting α2 agonist. When it activates the postsynaptic α2 receptors in vascular smooth muscle, there is a transient rise in the blood pressure. This is followed by activation of central α2 receptors, which results in decreases the central sympathetic tone and causes a prolonged fall in blood pressure.

α2 receptors are present postsynaptically in vascular walls and activation results in the same action as α1 stimulation i.e., vasoconstriction. But the major receptor that is responsible for vasoconstriction in vascular walls is the postsynaptic α1 receptor.

questions.text: In which of the following patients is therapy with an adrenergic-agonist not useful?

choices.text: 50-year-old woman suffering from acute decompensated heart failure
35-year-old man in septic shock with persistent hypotension

questions.solution:
Adrenergic agonists are not useful in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Adrenergic antagonists (phentolamine) are used locally for vasodilation in erectile dysfunction as PIPE therapy (Phentolamine Induced Penile Erection).

Adrenergic agonists are mainly sympathomimetic due to their action on peripheral vascular or post-synaptic alpha receptors. However, certain adrenergic agonists (like clonidine) act as a sympatholytic due to their predominant action on pre-synaptic α2 receptors which inhibits the release of noradrenaline.

Options A and B: In hypotensive states like shock and acute decompensated heart failure, short-term therapy with parenteral sympathomimetic drugs are indicated in treatment.

Option C: Clonidine is an adrenergic agonist which acts on the pre-synaptic α2 receptor and is used in the treatment of hypertension.

questions.text: A 22-week pregnant woman presents to the OPD for a routine check-up. On examination, her BP is 150/100 mmHg but she does not have a history of hypertension. You prescribe methyldopa to treat her. On which of the following receptors does this drug act?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a diagnosis of gestational hypertension, for which methyldopa is used. It acts on α2 receptors. 

Methyldopa is a centrally acting α2-adrenergic receptor agonist that is converted into alpha-methyl-norepinephrine. It decreases central sympathetic outflow, decreasing systemic vascular resistance without decreasing cardiac output.

questions.text: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug ‘X’. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug ‘X’?
questions.solution:
The probable mechanism of action of drug ‘X’ is β1 and β2 agonism.

According to the given table, systolic BP and heart rate is increased due to β1 agonistic effect, and diastolic BP is decreased by vasodilatation due to β2 action.

Option A: Action on α1 causes ↑ DBP

Option B: Action on M2 causes ↓ HR and action on M3 causes vasodilatation and reflex increase in HR. Hence there is no net effect on heart rate

Option C: α1 antagonism causes vasodilatation and ↓ DBP. β2 action causes vasodilatation and DBP ↓

questions.text: Which of the following is not an alpha adrenoreceptor agonist?
questions.solution:
Isoproterenol is a non-selective β-receptor agonist with no action on α-receptors. 

Clonidine, guanabenz, and guanfacine are α2 receptor agonists.

questions.text: Why is salbutamol preferred over adrenaline in the treatment of an asthmatic patient?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol is preferred over adrenaline in an asthmatic patient due to β2 selectivity.

This β2 selectivity is relative and lost at higher concentrations. Around 40% of the beta receptors are of β2 type and their activation won't cause cardiac stimulation.

Major adverse effects of non-selective β-agonists are attributed to the stimulation of β1 receptors in the heart which result in tachyarrhythmias. Selective β2 receptor agonists are introduced to overcome this major drawback.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man diagnosed with chronic bronchitis was prescribed a long-acting beta-2 agonist. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Formoterol is a long-acting β2 agonist (LABA).

β2 agonists are classified as:

  • Short-acting β2 receptor agonists (SABA):
    • Albuterol (Salbutamol)
    • Pirbuterol
    • Orciprenaline
  • Long-acting β2 agonists (LABA):
    • Salmeterol
    • Formoterol
  • Ultra-long acting β2 agonists (VLABA):
    • Indacaterol
    • Olodaterol
    • Vilanterol
    • Carmoterol

questions.text: Which of the following beta 2 receptor agonists was developed specifically as a uterine relaxant?
questions.solution:
Ritodrine was developed specifically as a uterine relaxant.

Salbutamol, orciprenaline, and terbutaline can also be used as uterine relaxants but were initially developed as inhalational agents for asthma. β2 agonists are associated with increased mortality and are rarely used as uterine relaxants now.

questions.text: A child suffering from intermittent bronchial asthma is being treated with β2 agonists. Which of the following side effects would you not expect?
questions.solution:
β2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to β2 receptor-mediated glycogenolysis and glucagon release.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists:

  • Hypokalemia - direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions
  • Tachycardia - reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on β2 receptors and direct effect on cardiac β1 receptors (β2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) 
  • Muscle tremors - direct effect on β2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Tolerance - desensitization on long-term use

questions.text:
A 4-year-old child on salbutamol is brought to the hospital with complaints of tremors. Which of the following effects of the drug would explain this side effect?
  1. Direct action on muscle spindles
  2. Hypokalemia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Direct action at the motor end-plate
  5. Hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Tremors due to β2 agonists can be both due to direct action on muscle spindle and hypokalemia.

Initially, it was thought to be due to beta receptor-mediated enhancement of discharge of muscle spindles. However, recently the tremors have also been closely correlated with hypokalemia. Hence both direct action and hypokalemia can explain the tremors associated with β2 agonist use, although the exact mechanism is still not known.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol in large doses can result in hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

Option A: Tachycardia due to reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on β2 receptors and direct effect on cardiac β1 receptors (β2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) 

Option B: Tolerance occurs due to desensitization on long-term use 

Option C: Hypokalemia due to direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with Parkinson's disease was prescribed mirabegron to control his symptoms of urinary urgency and incontinence. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Mirabegron is a β3 agonist used for the treatment of overactive bladder (OAB). Stimulation of β3 receptors in detrusor muscle increases the bladder capacity and provides symptomatic relief in overactive bladder.

Antimuscarinic drugs are the mainstay of oral pharmacological treatment for OAB. It acts by inhibiting muscarinic receptor subtypes, M2 and M3 in the bladder. Both subtypes are expressed in multiple tissues, resulting in anticholinergic adverse events such as dry mouth, constipation, and cognitive impairment. These adverse effects are not seen with mirabegron as it acts via adrenergic receptors.

Mirabegron is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6. Hence, caution has to be exercised when prescribing it along with CYP2D6 substrates such as metoprolol, desipramine, digoxin. 

Related Pearl: Muscarinic antagonists indicated for detrusor instability/overactive bladder

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and should be used very cautiously as slow bolus.

There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias).

For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1000 dilution can be used. 

In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use. The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of 1:10,000 solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

questions.text: A patient was treated for septicemia with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following best explains the benefit of this drug?
questions.solution:
The benefit of using noradrenaline in septicemia is that it increases the mean arterial blood pressure. It acts as a powerful peripheral vasoconstrictor and inotrope.

Noradrenaline causes a rise in both systolic BP and diastolic BP, resulting in a rise in the mean arterial blood pressure. This increases the organ perfusion in patients in septic shock or cardiogenic shock. 

Another advantage of noradrenaline is that it does so without causing tachycardia, which is often a troublesome event with other inotropes in critical care.

Options A and B: The rise in mean arterial pressure causes reflex bradycardia which is not a major contributor to the treatment of septic shock.

Option C: Low-dose dopamine infusions and furosemide are used to increase urine output in critically ill patients.

questions.text:
Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use:
A. 1:1000  1. Cardiac arrest
B. 1:10000  2. Anaphylaxis
C. 1:100000   3. Local anesthesia
questions.solution:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml I.M. is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV route, and used cautiously.

Adrenaline in a concentration of 1: 50,000 to 1: 200,000 is added to local anesthetics for:

  • Reducing the systemic absorption
  • Prolonging the duration of action
  • Providing a more bloodless field for surgery

1:1000 dilution can be used for the following routes of administration:

  • Intramuscular
  • Subcutaneous 
  • Inhalational (nebulization)

IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (ie, lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias). There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics, to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

Note: The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of a 1:10,000 solution administered IV every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines. For nebulization, 1:1000 adrenaline is commonly used.
